description.narrative: The Country Accelerator Labs are a three-year global initiative with a high level of ambition, driven by an innovative approach built on the best of current thinking.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.1.1 10 new sources of data 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.2.1 9 different type of data sources 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.3.1 50 new potential solutions 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses 1.4.1 10 innovation methods per Action Plan
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.1.1 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.2.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite. 2.3.1 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 2.4.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs - 48 interaction per year 3.1.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network.
3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.2.1 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network 3.3.1 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem. 3.4.1 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1.1 10 new sources of data Results: 7 new data sources (data from Community Volunteers, Private mobile network company data for mobile money transactions, Ministry of Agriculture home economics unit records).
1.2.1 9 different type of data sources: Results: 8 types of data sources (raw data files from Ministry of Agriculture home economics unit on existing cottage enterprises they established, Household mapping data of diaper users, Big data files from mobile company).
1.3.1 50 new potential solutions Results: 31 new solutions were mapped and uploaded to the global solutions platform. Seven of these were tested.
1.4.1 10 innovation methods per Action Plan Results: Action Plan 1 (Buy Swazi campaign) = 5 innovation methods were used namely co-creation, sensemaking, pilots, collective intelligence, solutions mapping. Action Plan 2 (Control and management of single use Diapers) = citizen science, cocreation, collective intelligence, sensemaking, randomised control trials innovation methods were used. Action plan 3 (Remote remand) = 5 innovation methods used namely; proof of concept, pilots, sensemaking, collective intelligence, co-creation.
2.1.1 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. Results: 5 blogs were published this year https://www.sz.undp.org/content/eswatini/en/home/blog.html (7 blogs were written this year, but only 5 were published); 1 two minutes video posted on Twitter, 3 campaign awareness videos posted on Facebook, 3 audio jingles broadcasted on national radio about the plastic bag campaign.
2.2.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. Results: 100% of all our learning challenges tackled have a public sector partner as a counterpart.
2.3.1 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. Results: In the work that we have done in the year we involved the following partners; a government entity Small and medium enterprise development company (SEDCO), Ministry of Commerce trade and Industry, Ministry of Tourism and Environmental Affairs and the Eswatini Environment Authority.
2.4.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects Results: A. the work that the Acclab did through the Phatsa sakho nawe project inspired a $600 000 Waste for livelihood projects and a $200 000 SGP Plastic project B. The work that the Acclab did on the informal sector in 2020 led to actionable knowledge to work that is being done under track 2. C. The sensemaking, solutions mapping, collective intelligence and exploration work done by the AccLab on enterprise development inspired a new project development in the Inclusive growth portfolio.
3.1.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. Results: The Acclab team takes part in the global calls weekly and interacts with the other labs in the network, All three members of the team are on WhatsApp groups and participate in global call within the 3 responsibility areas. The team has also engaged bilaterally with the labs in South Africa, Malawi, Mozambique, Lesotho, Gambia
3.2.1 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. Results: A. We shared methodology of single use plastic bags with Lesotho. This method was applicable in their context and seems to be bearing results. B. All the content that we published within the network and externally dealt with sustainable development issues and opportunities identified.
3.3.1 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. Results: The Acc lab has been featured in excess of XX times in CO social media channels this year (although although UNDP Acc lab accounts may not have been tagged
3.4.1 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. Results: our work on waste has allowed us engage with several new relevant local social media profiles via Environment Authority.

2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.1.1 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.2.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite. 2.3.1 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 2.4.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs - 48 interaction per year 3.1.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. Result:
3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.2.1 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network 3.3.1 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem. 3.4.1 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1.1 5 new sources of data – Results: 4 new data sources (informal trader data from the mother bodies we worked with showing traders data stratified per region, Mbabane city council registered informal trader numbers and types of businesses, Past studies conducted by agencies and partners on digital learning, Mobile network data showing student’s internet study bundle usage, Citizen perception data (primary data), data on plastic waste
1.2.1 6 different type of data sources – Results: 5 types of data sources were identified i.e. Mobile network, Municipality local economic development records, Citizen data (perception surveys and feedback mechanisms), Social network data, Plastic shopping bag stock data from retailers, Big and raw data
1.3.1 35 new potential solutions Results: 10 new solutions were mapped and uploaded to the global solutions platform. Four of these were tested.
1.4.1 5 innovation methods per Action Plan: Results: 4 Action plans were submitted in year 2020. Action plan 1(youth unemployment) = 6 innovation methods were used. Action plan 2 (digitalisation of education) = 5 innovation methods were used. Action plan 3 (informal sector digitalisation) = 3 innovation methods were used. Action plan 4 (Plastic bag) = 3 Innovation methods were used.
2.1.1 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. Results = 7 blogs were published this year; 1 policy brief on the informal sector was published
2.2.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. Results: All the learning challenges tackled had a combination of both public and other counterpart partners. In Action plan 1(youth unemployment) = 8 partners, Action plan 2 (digitalisation of education) = 5 partners, Action plan 3 (Informal sector digitalisation) = 12 partners, Action plan 4 (Plastic bag) = 9 partners
2.3.1 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. Results = For all the learning challenges tackled by the lab which were listed in 2.2.1, all had at least one government partner whom we worked with closely and got the opportunity to learn about the Acc lab methods. Results: In Action plan 1(youth unemployment) = 1 gov partner; Ministry of Commerce trade and industry MSME unit, Action plan 2 (digitalisation of education) = 1 partners; UNESWA, Action plan 3 (Informal sector digitalisation) = Ministry of Commerce trade and Industry; waste = 1 government partner (Ministry of Tourism and Environmental Affairs and the Eswatini Environment Authority)
2.4.1 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. Results: Our work on the informal sector has led to the Inclusive Growth Portfolio including the informal sector in the new CPD, Our work on waste has informed programming for a new $600,000.00 project on waste
3.1.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network 48 interaction per year. Results: The lab participates in global weekly calls. We also shared our learnings on education with Guinea-Bissau CO; we interacted with Zimbabwe and Lesotho labs on information sharing
3.2.1 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. Results: All the work we have shared has been sustainable development issues.
3.3.1 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. Results: The Acc lab has been featured in excess of 10 times in CO social media channels this year (although although UNDP Acc lab accounts may not have been tagged
3.4.1 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. Results: The Phatsa Sakho Nawe campaign has allowed us to engage broadly with local social media profiles on waste issues Our work with informal workers (i.e. the online shopping/ digital marketing experiments has allowed us to also engage broadly with social media profiles

Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

The Eswatini Acc Lab was fully assembled in November 2019. Due to the late start of the lab, the mandatory targets could not be met. However the team managed to achieve some milestones in the short period they had in 2019 financial year. - Ecosystem mapping and sense making was was conducted and youth unemployment was identified as the frontier challenge on which the lab would work on in 2019, prior to the teams arrival in the office. - The Eswatini AccLab was launched in December 2019. - The Accelerator lab Communication strategy was developed in December 2019.
